properties.Name: Dante
properties.Description: The author and protagonist of Inferno.

properties.Name: Virgil
properties.Description: Dante�s guide through the depths of Hell. Historically, Virgil lived in the first century B.C., in what is now northern Italy. Scholars consider him the greatest of the Latin poets.

properties.Name: Brutus and Cassius
properties.Description: Eternally eaten by Lucifer's three mouths are Brutus, Judas, and Cassius. Brutus and Cassius are punished in this lowest region for their assassination of Julius Caesar. Both Brutus and Cassius fought on the side of Pompey in the civil war. However, following Pompey's defeat at Pharsalia, Caesar pardoned them and invested them with high civic offices. They succeeded in assassinating Caesar but their political-military ambitions were soon thwarted by Octavian and Antony. For Dante, their betrayal of Julius Caesar, their benefactor and the world's supreme secular ruler, complements Judas Iscariot's betrayal of Jesus, the Christian man-god, in the Bible.

properties.Name: Pope Celestine V.
properties.Description: His refusal to perform the duties required of the pope (he abdicated five months after his election in July 1294) allowed Benedetto Caetani to become Pope Boniface VIII, the man who proved to be Dante's most reviled theological, political, and personal enemy.

properties.Name: Vanni Fucci
properties.Description: He was a black guelph from Pistoia. He admits to having stolen holy objects from a chapel in the Pistoian cathedral, a confession he did not offer when another man was accused of the crime and nearly executed before the true culprits were identified. Vanni subsequently gave up an accomplice, who was executed instead. Dante knew Vanni as a man "of blood and anger", he in fact committed numerous acts of violence, including murder, the thief actually gives God the proverbial finger.

properties.Name: Socrates
properties.Description: He was a classical Greek (Athenian) philosopher credited as one of the founders of Western philosophy. He is an enigmatic figure known chiefly through the accounts of classical writers, especially the writings of his students Plato and Xenophon.

properties.Name: Ulysses and Diomedes
properties.Description: Appearing in a single yet divided flame in the eighth pit of circle 8 are Ulysses and Diomedes, two Greek heroes from the war against Troy whose joint punishment reflects their many combined exploits. Virgil lists three offenses committed: devising and executing the stratagem of the wooden horse; luring Achilles into the war effort; and stealing the Palladium with the help of a Trojan traitor, Antenor.

properties.Name: Guido da Montefeltro
properties.Description: A fraudulent character who may himself be a victim of fraud. Guido was a sly military-political leader who knew "all the wiles and secret ways" of the world. He was a prominent ghibelline who led several important military campaigns in central Italy. Adviser to Pope Boniface VIII, da Montefeltro was promised anticipatory absolution�forgiveness for a sin given prior to the perpetration of the sin itself. Da Montefeltro now suffers in Hell, since absolution cannot be gained without repentance and it is impossible to repent a sin before committing it.

properties.Name: Mohammed and Ali
properties.Description: Both Mohammed--the founder of Islam--and his cousin and son-in-law Ali are depicted as sowers of religious divisiveness. One popular view held that Mohammed had himself been a cardinal who, his papal ambitions thwarted, caused a great schism within Christianity when he and his followers splintered off into a new religious community. He founded Islam in the early seventh century C.E. at Mecca. Ali married Mohammed's daughter, Fatima, but a dispute over Ali's succession to the caliphate led, after his assassination in 661, to a division among Muslims into Sunni and Shi'ite.

properties.Name: Bertran de Born
properties.Description: Bertran was a nobleman of a region, mostly contained in southern France, famous for the production of Proven�al literature. He allegedly instigated a rift between King Henry II of England and his son, the young prince Henry. Bertran is now himself physically divided: he carries his decapitated head.

properties.Name: Avicenna (Ibn Sina)
properties.Description: A great Islamic philosopher and a Persian polymath who is regarded as one of the most significant thinkers and writers of the Islamic Golden Age. Of the 450 works he is known to have written, around 240 have survived, including 150 on philosophy and 40 on medicine.

properties.Name: Pope Boniface VIII
properties.Description: A notoriously corrupt pope who reigned from 1294 to 1303, Boniface made a concerted attempt to increase the political might of the Catholic Church and was thus a political enemy of Dante, who advocated a separation of church and state.

properties.Name: Ugolino
properties.Description: Count Ugolino della Gherardesca earned his place in Antenora--the realm of political traitors--for a series of betrayals against Pisa and her political leadership. Born into a prominent ghibelline family in Pisa, Ugolino switched to the guelph side following their ascendancy in Tuscan politics and tried to install a guelph government in Pisa in 1274-5. Unsuccessful in this attempt, he was imprisoned and later exiled. Ugolino is eating the back of Ruggieri's head like a dog using its strong teeth to gnaw a bone as he ate his dead family members in prison.

properties.Name: Ruggieri
properties.Description: He captured Ugolino by deception, he imprisoned him, his two sons and his two nephews in the Torre della Muda, where they died. Probably for this reason, or for betraying the Visconti, Dante places Ruggieri in hell. Even Pope Nicholas IV rebuked Ruggieri for his behaviour and sent him a condemnation of his treatment of Ugolino and the Guelphs, but the pope's death prevented him acting on these and saved Ruggieri from punishment.

properties.Name: Fra Alberigo
properties.Description: Fra Alberigo and Branca d�Oria are unlike the other sinners Dante encounters: their crimes were deemed to be so great that devils snatched their souls from their living bodies; thus, their souls reside in Hell while their bodies live on, now guided and possessed by demons. A close relative, Manfred, plotted against Alberigo for political power; as a result of this dispute, Manfred struck Alberigo. Pretending that the altercation was forgotten, Alberigo invited Manfred and his son to a sumptuous banquet; when, at the end of the meal, the host gave the signal and slaughtered the guests.

properties.Name: Frederick II
properties.Description: Emperor Frederick II was important to Dante as the last in the line of reigning Holy Roman Emperors. Frederick was crowned emperor in Rome in 1220. A central figure in the conflicting claims of the empire and the papacy, he was twice excommunicated before his death in 1250. Frederick's court at Palermo was known as an intellectual and cultural capital, with fruitful interactions among talented individuals. Frederick's court nourished the first major movement in Italian vernacular poetry; this so-called "Sicilian School" of poetry contributed greatly to the establishment of the Italian literary tradition that influenced the young Dante.

properties.Name: Pier della Vigna
properties.Description: He was an accomplished poet and a victim of his own faithful service to the state. With a first-rate legal education and ample rhetorical talent, Pier rose quickly through the ranks of public service to judge and official spokesman for the imperial court of Frederick II. It is generally believed that he was falsely accused of betraying Frederick's trust by envious colleagues and political enemies. Frederick, believing the charges against Pier, had him imprisoned and blinded. Unable to accept this fate, Pier took his life by smashing his head against the wall or possibly by leaping from a high window as the emperor was passing below in the street.

properties.Name: Francesca (and Paolo)
properties.Description: Francesca da Rimini and Paolo Malatesta are punished together in hell for their adultery. Francesca was married for political reasons to Paolo's brother, Gianciotto ("Crippled John") of the powerful Malatesta family, rulers of Rimini. Francesca, according to Boccaccio, was blatantly tricked into marrying Gianciotto, who was disfigured and uncouth, when the handsome and elegant Paolo was sent in his brother's place to settle the nuptial contract. Francesca and Paolo, Boccaccio concludes, were buried--accompanied by many tears--in a single tomb.

properties.Name: Dido
properties.Description: Queen of Carthage and widow of Sychaeus, killed herself after her lover, Aeneas, abandoned her to continue his mission to establish a new civilization in Italy.

properties.Name: Guy de Montfort
properties.Description: An English nobleman who, to avenge his father, killed his cousin, Prince Henry of Cornwall.

properties.Name: Cleopatra
properties.Description: The beautiful Queen of Egypt, she took her own life to avoid capture by Octavian (the future emperor Augustus); Octavian had defeated Mark Antony, who was Cleopatra's lover (she had previously been the lover of Julius Caesar).

properties.Name: Hippocrates
properties.Description: He was a Greek physician of the Age of Pericles, and is considered one of the most outstanding figures in the history of medicine.

properties.Name: Saladin
properties.Description: He was the first sultan of Egypt and Syria and the founder of the Ayyubid dynasty.

properties.Name: Homer
properties.Description: Author of epic poems treating the war between the Greeks and Trojans (Iliad) and Ulysses' adventurous return voyage (Odyssey).

properties.Name: Aristotle
properties.Description: A student of Plato's, tutor to Alexander the Great, and founder of his own philosophical school (384-322 B.C.E.). "The master of those who know", he wrote highly influential works on an astonishing range of subjects, including the physical universe, biology, politics, rhetoric, logic, natural philosophy, metaphysics, and ethics.
